results.title: Especially the children
results.brief_description: In the developing world, simple survival is the basic need for many children and their families. UNICEF seeks for all children the basic rights and privileges set forth in the Declaration of the Rights of the Child.

results.title: Prostitute I am, common I'm not
results.brief_description: A revealing and honest film about five women who are prostitutes. They talk openly and intimately about themselves and their lives, telling why they do it, how they feel and how much they earn.

results.title: Wheat in Australia
results.brief_description: Primary teaching film surveying the wheat industry in Australia. Shows size and location of wheat areas, the beginnings of Governor Phillip’s 8-acre plot in 1788, the work of William Farrar in breeding new strains suited to Australian conditions from 1889 onwards, and the cycle of work which continues year after year on a modern mechanised farm. Discusses climate and soil requirements of wheat and explains why Australia’s wheat belt is situated between the 10-20 inches rainfall areas.

results.title: A Crime to fit the punishment
results.brief_description: In 1954, during the height of McCarthyism and the Cold War, the controversial labour film ‘Salt of the Earth’ was made despite numerous attempts by the film industry and the U.S. government to prevent its production. This film explores the background that surrounded the film’s production, combining interviews and production footage with newsclips and broadcasts from the early fifties. It captures the struggle of the blacklisted Hollywood film people who defiantly set out to commit a crime to fit their punishment. Narrated by Lee Grant.

results.title: The Cordellera Expedition
results.brief_description: Follows an expedition retracing the steps of Canada’s early explorers including the use of stills and archival footage. Spectacular scenery and wildlife images make this film a must for those who love the outdoors.

results.title: Human nature and organizational realities (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William C. Jersey, Howard Enders, BNA Communications and Quest Productions
results.brief_description: Discusses Chris Argyris’ theory that worker apathy is not due to laziness but rather a healthy reaction to an unhealthy environment created by common management policies. The typical organisation confines most of its employees to roles that provide little opportunity for responsibility, self reliance or independence. Explains how executive interpersonal relations can be improved.
